necessary for the completion of
the experiments.

" Modern Medley," submitted
anonymously by Diana Rogge, a
Baltimorean and former student at
the Hopkins, was named the winner
of the national play contest held by
the Hopkins Playshop for an original American play to be presented
April 11, 14, 15, and 16. The
judges, Chester Morrow, of the
Vagabonds ; Donald Kirkley, dramatic critic of the S1m; and Dr. N.
Bryllion Fagin, director of the Playshop, called the comedy an exceptional piece.

Loeb Embryonic Findings Not Surprising To
Hopkins Zoologist

Lehigh Paper Protests
$1500 Week-End
House Party

Commenting upon the findings
of Prof. Leo Loeb, Dr. R. P.
Cowles, professor of ZoOlogy at
he Hopkins, said today that he
'cannot see any good reason why,
occasionally, he should not find
embryo beginnings' in the ovaries
of guinea pigs, even when no
fertilization occurred."
The Anatomical Record decribes the findings of Dr. Loeb,
of Washington University Medical School. They are based on
actual observations in which parhenogenetic embryonic structures had been found in virgin
guinea pigs.

Though its official acceptance was
not announced as late as yesterday
afternoon, it was revealed by officials or the Cotillon Board that the
organization has established an artnual grant, bearing a stipend of
$250 and to be known as the CotilIon Board Grant.
No Specifications Yet
No specifications as to the qualifications of the recipient were made
known by the organization. The
dean of the College of Arts and
Sciences, Dr. E. W. Berry, is to
choose, after consultation with
President Joseph S. Ames, the recipient for 1931-32 at once. The
second grant is to be awarded in
September, 1933, it was said.

The annual home concert of the
Johns Hopkins Musical Club will
be presented today at 8 :30 P . M.
at the Maryland Casualty Auditorium. The sponsor of the concert and of the dance which is to
follow will be Miss Annette Webster, a student at Goucher College.
Music for the dance will be provided by Osmar Steinwald and his
Eleven Clubmen, it was said.
The concert will include numbers
by the Glee Club, Banjo Club,
Hawaiian Troupe, Blue Jay Orchestra, and a soloist. The Glee
Club is directed by Steinwald, the
Banjo Club and Hawaiian Troupe
by Conrad Gebelein, and the Blue
Jay Orchestra is led by J. L. Sullivan. Donald Proctor will be the
soloist.

cut in armament In answer to the
query: "Should the United States
disarm independent .of other nations ?" , 364 answered in the negative and 66 in the affirmative, the

Definite knowledge of "where we are" and
"what lies ahead" is as vital in business as in
flying. For this expert navigating, the Bell
System has long relied upon statisticians.
These men study present and prospective
industrial, economic and social conditions in
all parts of the country. They gather factsanalyze them, correlate them, discover their
significance to the telephone business, draw
guidance from them. They study and fore-

cast the changing requirements of the public
for telephone service. They estimate the
probable future demand for new servicesp
such as radio telephony to foreign lands and
ships at sea. They keep the executives advised
as to current progress towards the objectives
thus carefully determined.
Only by plotting a course scientifically can
the Bell System continue to develop along
sound lines.

chemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will be the
fourth A. R. L. Dahme lecturer.

March 18.

atoms and groups in organic compounds, the mechanism of reactions, and pyrolysis. {Iis work as

in the field of petroleum, and in
industrial preparation of aromatic
compounds by new methods.

whose lecture topic has not been
announced, will discuss some phase
of chemical experimentation in
which he has recently been engaged.
In 1892, Dr. Norris received his
A. B. degree and in 1895 his Ph. D.
at the Johns Hopkins. F'Or the year
1894-95 he held a fellowship in

Sc. D. degree was conferred on Dr.

Determines Stress Conditions
"This model is not, as one
would suppose, a more or less exact replica of the bridge nor is it
loaded with weights of any kind.
Instead it is sawed out of a thin
sheet of uniform thickness, the
members being proportional to
the stiffness of the actual members by varying their width. At
any point where it is desired to
know the stress conditions the
model is cut through and slightly
deformed by a Beggs gauge at
that point. A survey is then made
of deflections at points on the
arch roadway where loads would
be applied to the actual structure.
Certain laws discovered by the
physicist Maxwell makes it possio arrive at the stress condition

rue structure.

are being made to structures

o highly indeterminate as to
ender a mathematical treatment

Most Eligible Class Of Marriageable Girls In The World
Find "Trial Marriage"' "Companionate Marriage" All
Greek To Them; Believe In Old Fashioned Form
(Special To The News Letter)

The most eligible class of marriageable girls in the world, the 75
beauties in the Ziegfeld Follies,
don't seem to agree completely
with the Bryn Mawr girls in the
recently conducted survey.
The Ziegfeld girls believe in the
matter of marriage, according to a
good, old-fashioned form of marriage, when and if they get married. Seventy of the 75 girls believe in marriage as an· institution.
Five of them were married and
would just like to take things easy
for a while. The 70 who vote for
marriage want their union to be
based on the shibboleths and principles which guided the marriages
of their parents.
Desire Old Fashioned Form
The galaxy of noted beauties,
undoubtedly the most sought after
girls in all the world, just don't
want to get all tangled up in the
various versions that have accompanied the muchly discussed forms
of "trial marriage" and "companionate marriage." To them the conflict of ideas on these two forms
of marriage is just so much Greek.
They desire the old fashioned form.
Questionnaires are unnecessary anent the matter of marriage
of Follies beauties. A marriage of

a Ziegfeld girl is front page news
importance. Turning back the
pages of the big metropolitan
papers would reveal that one girl
out of eighteen marries a socalled millionaire. The rest of
the marriagable beauties seem to
find their love and happiness in
the personages of their home
town boy friend, a struggling
college student, a nice working
fellow, and occasionally a newspaper man.
Want Real Love
Like the Bryn Mawr girls, the
Follies beauties value real love
and loyalty above all else. They
should know. The Bryn Bawr
girls gave the physical compatibility thing an eight per cent
rating. The Follies girls can't
agree on just what rating that
part of marriage should get. It
takes two, the man and the woman, to arrive at that percentage.
When discussing Follies girls,
it might be said that if past
figures and facts are to be considered, and the amount of highly
educated people of the male
species who have married Follies
girls are to be taken into that
summary, then it is safe to as( Continued on page 3, column 5)

April 12 Set For Y. M.

Besides setting April 12 as the
date for the election of next
year's officers and May 3 as their
installation date, the Y. M. C. A.
Cabinet, Tuesday night, passed on
several other matters pertaining
to business for 1932-33.
Glass, Mount and Johnson
were appointed as a nominating
committee to select candidates
for the offices of president, vicepresident, secretary, and treasurer, which officers will be
elected April 12. After these officers have chosen the remainder
of their Cabinet, the entire organization will be installed at a
supper meeting May 3.
Further discussion was held
concerning the work on the 193233 Handbook and the time and
place of the Cabinet "retreat,"
which is annually held by the "Y"
to discuss plans for the coming

On Strike As Largest Source
Oflncome Is Tabooed In Women's College Where Girls
Aren't Allowed To Smoke On Campus
By N. S. F. A.

NEW YORK, N. Y. - The
Hunter Bulletin, student publication at Hunter College, was out
on the campus last week, but its
masthead bore the legend, "Published by Student Council," instead of the names of the editorial
staff, which quit in a body.
A four-column editorial and a
statement bearing the names of
the former members of the
"Bully" staff, explained their action in detail.
Cigarette Ads Taboo
The staff declared that Dr.
James M. Kieran, president of the
college, had "refused The Bulletin
the use of cigarette advertisements, the main source of income" for the publication, which
meants that the paper could print
only four pages weekly instead of
six, with a consequent lowering
of editorial standards. The staff
also felt, it said, that it "must
keep its pledge to the Women's
Intercollege News Associationto allow no interefrence with
college publications by the administration, the faculty or the
alumnae."
For a period last term the
"Bully" ran an advertisement of
a large tobacco company. It was
the largest ad, in the publication,
but when the contract ran out it
was not renewed. At the meeting of the Student Council the
staff stood firm for permission to
run the advertisement and re-

fused to get out the following
clay's issue. A staff was then
hastily assembled by the council.
Not Permitted To Smoke
The dispute over the cigarette
advertisement has its roots fat
in the past. Hunter girls are not
permitter to smoke on the college
grounds. They have agitated, at
various times, for a special smoking room, but without success.
Miss Henrietta T,!ichy, president of the Student Council, called
the resignation "regrettable," and
said that while she sympathized
with the ideals of the old staff,
she felt its methods had been "objectionable." She also questioned
the journalistic ethics of the
resignation.
Staff Holds Off Copy
The staff would not permit the
use, for Monday's issue of the
Bulletin, of the material it had
prepared last week. An emergency staff assembled by the Student Council got the paper out.
Miss Tichy objected to the
joint statement of the staff that
cigarette advertising had been
chief source of income.
"That is a misstatement," she
declared. "Examination of The
Bulletin accounts revealed that
more than half the paper's funds
were derived from Student Council appropriations and subscriptions, and that about one-third of
its income came from the total
amount of advertising profits."

fol" each.

that's what the
statistician does for industry
Definite knowledge of "where we are" and
"what lies ahead" is as vital in business as in
flying. For this expert navigating, the Bell
System has long relied upon statisticians.
These men study present and prospective
industrial, economic and social conditions in
all parts of the country. They gather factsanalyze them, correlate them, discover their
significance to the telephone business, draw
guidance from them. They study and fore-

cast the changing requirements of the public
for telephone service. They estimate the
probable future demand for new servicesp
such as radio telephony to foreign lands and
ships at sea. They keep the executives advised
as to current progress towards the objectives
thus carefully determined.
Only by plotting a course scientifically can
the Bell System continue to develop along
sound lines.

--The man who says that humanity is suffering from a severe
attack of repentance, Gerhart
Hauptmann, noted German author, will be discussed as an intellect and dramatist by Dr. Ernst
Feise, professor of German, in the
Hopkins man's lecture Sunday
evening at the Playshop.
Herr Hauptmann, who is
traveling in America in connection with the celebration of the
200th anniversary of Goethe's
birth, has chosen the Johns Hopkins as one of three American
universities at which he will
speak. He will apear here next
Friday, it was said.
The dramatist, upon his arrival

Dr. James F. Norris, director of
the research laboratory of organic
chemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will be the
fourth A. R. L. Dahme lecturer.
He is to speak at the Hopkins on
March 18.
In recent )'ears, Dr. Norris' academic research has been in the
field of the chemical reactivity of
atoms and groups in organic compounds, the mechanism of reactions, and pyrolysis. {Iis work as
consulting chemist has been largely
in the field of petroleum, and in
industrial preparation of aromatic
compounds by new methods.
It is expected that Dr. Norris,
whose lecture topic has not been
announced, will discuss some phase
of chemical experimentation in
which he has recently been engaged.
In 1892, Dr. Norris received his
A. B. degree and in 1895 his Ph. D.
at the Johns Hopkins. F'Or the year
1894-95 he held a fellowship in
chemistry here.
The honorary
Sc. D. degree was conferred on Dr.
Norris by Bowdoin College in 1929.
He has been at M. I. T. since 1916.

Determines Stress Conditions
"This model is not, as one
would suppose, a more or less exact replica of the bridge nor is it
loaded with weights of any kind.
Instead it is sawed out of a thin
sheet of uniform thickness, the
members being proportional to
the stiffness of the actual members by varying their width. At
any point where it is desired to
know the stress conditions the
model is cut through and slightly
deformed by a Beggs gauge at
that point. A survey is then made
of deflections at points on the
arch roadway where loads would
be applied to the actual structure.
Certain laws discovered by the
physicist Maxwell makes it possio arrive at the stress condition
at the corresponding point in the
rue structure.

of this principle of stress analysis
are being made to structures

o highly indeterminate as to
ender a mathematical treatment
out of the question."

Most Eligible Class Of Marriageable Girls In The World
Find "Trial Marriage"' "Companionate Marriage" All
Greek To Them; Believe In Old Fashioned Form
(Special To The News Letter)

The most eligible class of marriageable girls in the world, the 75
beauties in the Ziegfeld Follies,
don't seem to agree completely
with the Bryn Mawr girls in the
recently conducted survey.
The Ziegfeld girls believe in the
matter of marriage, according to a
good, old-fashioned form of marriage, when and if they get married. Seventy of the 75 girls believe in marriage as an· institution.
Five of them were married and
would just like to take things easy
for a while. The 70 who vote for
marriage want their union to be
based on the shibboleths and principles which guided the marriages
of their parents.
Desire Old Fashioned Form
The galaxy of noted beauties,
undoubtedly the most sought after

the personages of their home
town boy friend, a struggling
college student, a nice working
fellow, and occasionally a newspaper man.

rating. The Follies girls can't

April 12 Set For Y. M.
C.A. Election For
1'932-33
Besides setting April 12 as the
date for the election of next
year's officers and May 3 as their
installation date, the Y. M. C. A.
Cabinet, Tuesday night, passed on
several other matters pertaining
to business for 1932-33.
Glass, Mount and Johnson
were appointed as a nominating
committee to select candidates
for the offices of president, vicepresident, secretary, and treasurer, which officers will be
elected April 12. After these officers have chosen the remainder
of their Cabinet, the entire organization will be installed at a
supper meeting May 3.
Further discussion was held
concerning the work on the 193233 Handbook and the time and
place of the Cabinet "retreat,"
which is annually held by the "Y"
to discuss plans for the coming
year.
After the business session, the
Cabinet met with Rev. Graham
Ll!.cy, of the Franklin Street
Presbyterian Church, to discuss
some of the problems confronting religion today.

On Strike As Largest Source
Oflncome Is Tabooed In Women's College Where Girls
Aren't Allowed To Smoke On Campus
By N. S. F. A.

NEW YORK, N. Y. - The
Hunter Bulletin, student publication at Hunter College, was out
on the campus last week, but its
masthead bore the legend, "Published by Student Council," instead of the names of the editorial
staff, which quit in a body.
A four-column editorial and a
statement bearing the names of
the former members of the
"Bully" staff, explained their action in detail.
Cigarette Ads Taboo
The staff declared that Dr.
James M. Kieran, president of the
college, had "refused The Bulletin
the use of cigarette advertisements, the main source of income" for the publication, which
meants that the paper could print
only four pages weekly instead of
six, with a consequent lowering
of editorial standards. The staff
also felt, it said, that it "must
keep its pledge to the Women's
Intercollege News Associationto allow no interefrence with
college publications by the administration, the faculty or the
alumnae."
For a period last term the
"Bully" ran an advertisement of
a large tobacco company. It was
the largest ad, in the publication,
but when the contract ran out it
was not renewed. At the meeting of the Student Council the
staff stood firm for permission to
run the advertisement and re-

fused to get out the following
clay's issue. A staff was then
hastily assembled by the council.
Not Permitted To Smoke
The dispute over the cigarette
advertisement has its roots fat
in the past. Hunter girls are not
permitter to smoke on the college
grounds. They have agitated, at
various times, for a special smoking room, but without success.
Miss Henrietta T,!ichy, president of the Student Council, called
the resignation "regrettable," and
said that while she sympathized
with the ideals of the old staff,
she felt its methods had been "objectionable." She also questioned
the journalistic ethics of the
resignation.
Staff Holds Off Copy
The staff would not permit the
use, for Monday's issue of the
Bulletin, of the material it had
prepared last week. An emergency staff assembled by the Student Council got the paper out.
Miss Tichy objected to the
joint statement of the staff that
cigarette advertising had been
chief source of income.
"That is a misstatement," she
declared. "Examination of The
Bulletin accounts revealed that
more than half the paper's funds
were derived from Student Council appropriations and subscriptions, and that about one-third of
its income came from the total
amount of advertising profits."
